content.description: Apologies to those primates who are less than 5'9" tall.  There is a height dependent crux at the second bolt.  This being said, there are intermediate moves (perhaps harder than the rating) to reach that critical finger edge. The rest of the climb is stiff with good movement.  Small edges and big throws get you to the left shoulder of Swift Spire where you can place more gear and start the traverse right to the anchor.
content.protection: Three bolts, a BD .3 and #2 gets you to the chains.
content.location: Head down the fixed line from the edge but just to the last "U" bolt. Here you leave the rope and head across the talus SW a short distance to a small rise. Take the easy line down and SW before cutting back to the wall and the obvious spire. Edge to spire about 3 min.s

climbs.name: Titmouse
climbs.fa: Phyllis Suggett, RoySuggett, Brittany Black and Jandro Pabon Sanclemente

content.description: A fun slab on good rock that is well protected. Passing the second bolt is the most problematic though shooing away Titmice while on lead can also be cruxie.
content.protection: Five QDs will get you to a two bolt anchor with a quicklink.
content.location: Opposite the main wall and facing west this line is easy to spot.  Come down the chute on the fixed line and turn left or northeast.  Cross some big blocky talus to reach the large flat rock at the route's base.

content.description: Start at seam in low point of area through crux  to belay (for 70) at about 70ft.  Continue on for upper face that is a little run on 5.8-9 to second belay at 120 ft.  Upper belay requires 80 m rope to reach bottom or use of  belay for 70.
content.location: Route is right of 70 10 feet or so.

content.description: move up through questionable rock but great climbing to better rock and climbing above
content.location: Clip fist bolt of 70 and climb left following faint seam until going right to belay.  Seam visible in picture of 70/Subtrefuge.

content.description: Several high steps on Swift Spire's blocky NE shoulder gets you to a tip toe traverse to climbers right.  Here you find the anchor on the opposite shoulder of this little spire.  Gear is placed from good stances.
content.protection:
Passive = A set of small to medium nuts.

Active = A BD .3 through a #2 X 1.

Anchor = Two bolts and chains.

Check out the FA rack photo.
content.location: Head down the fixed line from the edge but just to the last "U" bolt.  Here you leave the rope and head across the talus SW a short distance to a small rise.  Take the easy line down and SW before cutting back to the wall and the obvious spire.  Edge to spire about 3 min.s

content.description:
This two-pitch route is in the “S” shape of a Flamingo’s neck.  Like most pink flamingos-animate or inanimate and wherever they appear-they make a statement. This line does the same and follows the best rock and more-or-less stays with the overhanging arete.  The anchor is also above both a possible trad and sport lines which looks significantly harder but on great rock.  Feel free to set these up using the anchor and high bolts.  You are welcomed to them.  The Pink Flamingo however, stays left on the arete with more moderate climbing before turning right to the anchor that would cover the future more difficult projects below.

PI - 25 feet

Start with your back to Kestrel Tower and have the leader muscle up the short one bolt chimney to the large ledge with two bolts and a chain.  The second will no longer give you crap about your groveling in the chimney after they join you atop this comfortable ledge.  This, like most chimneys, is awkward and goes about 5.9.

PII - 65 feet

Keep the belayer at the anchor where more protection is afforded from any unpredicted rock fall and send the stronger leader up the face at the south end of the ledge.  Clip the first bolt long.  The second clip is up and left toward a notch in the arete.  Mantle atop the blocky cut out in the arete and place a BD .4 here clipped long.  The next moves are a sketchy traverse toward an awkward side pull.  Move up a bit to a better stance and clip another bolt long prior to reaching far right and pulling your gear and straightening your line.  More side pulls will get you to the fourth bolt where a 4’ runner would help.  Up and right back to the arete through thin edging and arete climbing.  Cross over to the high face above and work right and up to the anchor or clip here and top out in only a few moves.  There seems to be two cruxes.  Both in the upper half of this pitch, each a different kind of problem and each in the high 10s.
content.protection:
Active- BD .4 X 1

QDs X 5

Two ft. runners X 3

Four ft. runner X 1

Anchor- Chain and a quicklink on two bolts.

Rope-  This can be done in one pitch IF you use a 70 m rope AND the leader frees

the first pitch.  Otherwise, if done in two pitches, you can use a 60 m

rope but must rap twice.
content.location: Just climber's left from Bird of Prey and in front of Kestrel Tower.

climbs.name: Merlin
climbs.fa: Roy Suggett, Andy Ross and Gene Vallee

content.description: The old saying "Do Not Judge A Book By Its Cover" very much applies here!  We thought this would go much easier... but we were fooled badly.  A Merlin is a very small raptor and a master of trickery.  The start is a bit spicy (Anaheim) but the ending is a Serrano Pepper for sure!  That last set of moves past the last bolt will bring on "Mexican Heart Burn"
content.protection: Four QDs and runners for the anchor on top of Kestrel Tower.
content.location: On the NW side of Kestrel Tower which is mid way through the Flying Raptors Area.  Edge top to tower 8 min.s

content.description: Very good moderate with lots of movement.  The bolts are fairly close and the stances are solid.  After topping out on the south side of the tower you will need to carefully make your way across the top of the tower to reach the chains on the north side.   You will be doing face, arete, and mantle moves giving this line 3 stars!
content.protection: Four QDs and runners for the chains.
content.location: This route starts on the SW side of Kestrel Tower and moves around the arete right to the south face were the four bolts are located.

climbs.name: In the Eyrie of the Beholder

content.description: Start in the obvious chimney where the Carion Pillar meets the main wall. After approximately 12 feet, a crack (visible from start) provides the first piece of protection. Two ledges interrupt the continuous chimney and provide the cruxes of the route with the one requiring a less than sexy belly flop. Unlike most chimneys, this route allows gear every 10-12 feet. For some this may feel PG rated as there is ground fall potential at the start and after one of the ledges however all the cruxes are decently protected. Chains are located at the final roof at the end of the chimney and allows for easy topropping. This is a good summer respite for desert chimney addicts when the red desert is too hot or a good practice route for the burgeoning chimney leader.
content.protection: See image below. You could get by with doubles from BD 0.4 - 2, single of BD 3, and medium stoppers.
content.location: Start in the obvious chimney where the Carion Pillar meets the main wall.

climbs.name: Falco
climbs.fa: Andy Ross, Gene Vallee & Roy Suggett

content.description: Fun slapping up the steep arete which can be lead or toproped from Bird of Prey.
content.location:
Arete right of Bird of Prey.

Directly behind Merlin.

climbs.name: Carrion Pillar
climbs.fa: Andy Ross, Gene Vallee & Roy Suggett

content.description: A nice steady climb with a few tricky sections to keep your intrest.
content.location: The obvious pillar in the middle of the crag.

climbs.name: Bushtit
climbs.fa: Jandro Pabon Sanclemente, Brittany Black, Phyllis & Roy Suggett

content.description: An easy to protect crack on good rock.  The line joins Titmouse at the last bolt.  This would be a great place to learn to set gear.
content.protection: BD .5 through a #2 X 1.  Then one QD for the final bolt shared with Titmouse.
content.location: Just left of Titmouse in the obvious hand crack.

climbs.name: Bird of Prey.
climbs.fa: Gene Vallee, Roy Suggett & Andy Ross

content.location: Starts up the obvious face/corner 20ft behind Merlin.

content.description: Bouldery moves at first are the crux!  After these north face thinkers, clip the bolt and move left across the arete to better rock thus avoiding the sketchy blocks (your belayer is praying that you avoid these blocks).  The rest of the climbing is reachy and slightly over hung on good stone.  The crack protects well and the last section is really fun.
content.protection: BD .3,.4, and a .5 X 1 (I used a brown Camp Tricam) as well as three QDs and runners for the top.  There is now a chain with a quick link at the top.
content.location: This line starts on the north side of Kestrel Tower and then moves around the arete and onto the east face.

climbs.name: Bird Brain
climbs.fa: Andy Ross, Gene Vallee & Roy Suggett

content.description: Easy start leads to some hard moves across the face. Finish up right to anchor.
content.location: Starts up the first clean sweep of rock on the descent, about 100yds left of Carrion Pillar.

climbs.name: The Ascent of Man
climbs.fa: Zac Warren, Christy "Kezzie" Shuster, Roy Suggett

content.description:
This beautiful laser cut roof crack is one of the best cracks in the jungle.

Begin on easy terrain before pure fist jams lead you to a 4' roof.

Jam through the roof on fists/cupped hands and only 6' and a few roof moves await you before clipping the chains.

It is recommended to place a BD#3 in the last roof crack above and left of the chains as a high point for your 2nd.

Then redirect the rope through the chains. The anchor placement makes things a little funky but allows for zero rope drag and possible 2nd pitch (11+).

This route protects like a dream and is a great introduction into wide roof cracks. It remains shady all day and is blocked from the wind.
content.protection: BD#4(x4) and BD#3(x3) will allow you to sew it up. Once you hit the roof, the crack narrows to #3s.
content.location: Across from Kestrel Tower and the small block that holds Falco and Bird of Prey.

content.description: A very fun start on the face left of the arete.  Clip the only bolt and move right to the arete.  Here you can place gear in the crack as you climb up the arete to the anchor.  Fun moves!
content.protection: One QD and the rest of the line is easy placements of BD .4 & a .75.
content.location: Head down the fixed line from the edge but just to the last "U" bolt. Here you leave the rope and head across the talus SW a short distance to a small rise. Take the easy line down and SW before cutting back to the wall and the obvious spire. Edge to spire about 3 min.s

content.description: Climb solid broken rock left of short smooth slab to shallow corner at bolt 3.  Follow corner  through distinctive crux and crack to belay.
content.location: Right of Carrion at short smooth face.
